titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Alumni
titleInfo.subTitle: Glenn Lewis McMullen oral history interview, 1996

name.description: Glen Lewis McMullen was born in 1945, in Washington, D.C. His father, Louie McMullen, was a World War II navy veteran who worked for the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey in New Orleans. His mother, Jean Cloud, was primarily a homemaker. McMullen grew up in Kenner, Louisiana, and attended East Jefferson High School in Metairie. He began his college career in 1963 at Northeast Louisiana State College, but soon transferred to LSU-New Orleans, and then to LSU-Baton Rouge in 1964. He received several degrees form LSU: a B.A. in Philosophy in 1968, an M.A. in European History in 1972, and an MLIS in 1979. He has worked for the New Orleans Public Library, LSU Libraries, and the Indiana Historical Society. McMullen is now an independent contractor in publishing, living with his wife, Judy, in Austin, Texas.

subject.topic: Delta Tau Delta Fraternity.--Epsilon Kappa Chapter (Louisiana State University)

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Glenn McMullen recalls his years at Louisiana State University as an undergraduate and graduate student in the mid to late 1960s and early 1970s. He discusses his anti-Vietnam War activism, especially a 1967 protest that he helped organize with fellow philosophy student, Don Baker. He shares memories of his ROTC duties, his fraternity involvement with Delta Tau Delta, a job at Edwards' Orange Bowl, and of philosophy classes, professors, and fellow students. He recalls people's reactions to the Kennedy and King assassinations. He discusses growing up in Kenner, Louisiana, his early education, high school fraternity culture, and a few memories of race relations and school desegregation.
